awd_titl_txt: Disentangling liquid-liquid phase separation and aggregation of intrinsically disordered proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins and nucleic acids can physically partition without the help of membranes.  These assemblies behave like liquid droplets and provide a dynamic environment for biomolecular reactions requiring specific protein concentrations.  Some of these proteins are also known to aggregate and cause neurodegenerative diseases.  This raises the key question how the functional liquid droplets transform into the pathological solid aggregates.   In this research, advanced computational methods will be used to view how the structures of these proteins differ in the liquid droplets and aggregates.  The knowledge learned from this project will be essential in designing novel strategies that can disrupt pathological aggregates but do not disrupt functional droplets.  The concepts of computational modeling will be introduced into both the undergraduate research and high school biophysics apprenticeship programs at Arizona State University (ASU), a university with a significant underrepresented student population in a location that is home to a large number of individuals from underrepresented groups in STEM.  The PI will pay specific attention to promoting a variety of dissemination approaches through the ASU expert database to introduce the concepts of biophysics and to facilitate the dissemination of materials to a broad audience.

Intrinsically disordered proteins, proteins that lack a well-defined folded structure, have been shown to participate in both liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) and aggregation.  The former is reversible, providing important intracellular functions, whereas the latter is often irreversible and disease-related.  There has been increasing interest in showing how droplet formation could induce aggregation, but little is known regarding the structure properties capable of distinguishing these two assembly states.  One major challenge is the lack of high-resolution modeling methods for integrating observations from multiple experimental techniques.  In this work, the PIs will develop a novel computational modeling framework to integrate multiple technologies.  Specifically, all-atom explicit-solvent simulations will be used to investigate the structure properties of disordered proteins in both dispersed and condensed phases and how these properties are influenced by their interaction partners.  Coarse-grained models will further be used to investigate both the formation of liquid droplets and aggregates.  The impact of droplet formation on its aggregation preference will be quantitatively assessed.  The project will leverage computational tools to establish fundamental physics principles that govern the structural (dis)similarities between LLPS and aggregation.

por.por_cntn:
Proteins can form condensates without membranes, behaving like dynamic liquid-like droplets, and contribute to intracellular compartmentalization. However, some of them are also known to form solid aggregates, which are related to neurodegenerative diseases. The intrinsically disordered protein (IDP) is one type of proteins playing key roles in forming these two assembly states. This grant has supported my lab at Arizona State University in understanding the similarities and differences of these two assembly states as well as attracting and training next-generation biophysicists. We have explored three modeling topics with the main outcomes listed below.

First, we improved our coarse-grained HPS model to study the liquid-liquid phase separation of IDPs. This model simplifies each amino acid in the protein to a single bead, allowing for direct simulation of co-existing high- and low-density phases.  We incorporated the salting-out effect into the model to describe the conformational properties across a wide range of salt concentrations. Additionally, simple polynucleotides were parametrized into the model to simulate the co-phase separation of proteins and nucleic acids. The model has been made available on GitHub and our lab's website and has been used in various cases, including diffusion of an IDP on its folded ligand.

Second, we used a more detailed all-atom explicit-solvent simulations to look at key interactions within these droplets. This method provides a high-resolution view compared to the previous coarse-grained model, offering detailed insights into specific types of interactions. However due to complexity of the system, direct co-existence simulations with all-atom explicit-solvent models are not feasible. We therefore developed a framework that first equilibrates the system using coarse-grained simulations and then applies all-atom models. The model captured the diffusion of protein and water molecules inside the condensates, consistent with experimental measurements. We found that the self-association of IDPs is not only driven by a combination of specific interactions such as hydrogen bonds and salt bridges but also nonspecific hydrophobic interactions.

Third, we investigated the relationship between the liquid and solid assembly states of IDPs. We found that specific charge arrangement in a sequence like alpha-Synuclein leads to different sequence determinants for each state. In collaboration with an experimental lab, we showed these states can be independent to each other in different salt concentrations and interconverted through prolonged incubation. This phenomenon can be explained by the interplay between specific interactions within the protein, regulating the solvent exposure of the aggregation region, and nonspecific interactions between proteins, controlling how they come together and phase separate.
